I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Kyrgyz Republic for the Second Vocational Education 
and Skills Development Project.1 
2.  The project seeks to improve the quality and relevance of, and equitable access to and 
effectiveness of, the technical and vocational education and training (TVET) system in the 
Kyrgyz  Republic.  Quality  and  relevance  of  the  TVET  system  will  be  improved  through 
modernization of the training methodology, teaching and learning environments, and training 
delivery. Equitable access will be improved through the introduction of an innovative skills 
development fund to provide training in response to urgent labor market needs, and for targeting 
specific geographic areas or specific groups to provide them with employable skills, such as out-
of-school youths, ethnic minorities, and the disabled. The project also includes support to rural 
primary  vocational  schools  outside  of  Bishkek  and  Osh,  and  better  access  for  physically 
disabled students and for women. The effectiveness of the TVET system will be improved by 
strengthening TVET governance and management nationally and within the schools. 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The  Government  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  recently  approved  its  Medium-Term 
Development  Program,  2012–2014,  aiming  for  an  average  growth  rate  of  6%  per  annum 
anchored on the robust expansion of seven priority sectors2 that are expected to drive the 
economy and create jobs for the growing number of unemployed, particularly among youths (in 
2010, 17.1% of female youths and 12.2% of male youths were unemployed). However, many 
enterprises experience difficulties in finding skilled workers, underscoring the mismatch between 
the outputs of the education and training sector and labor market needs. This shortage of skilled 
labor is a binding constraint on economic growth. 
4.  The project will help remove this constraint by supporting the modernization of the TVET 
system in rural and urban areas. It will focus on the seven priority sectors (footnote 2) and 
involve employers in selecting the key occupations and determining the skills required for these 
occupations. It will help meet the needs of the labor market. 
5.  The TVET system is composed of primary TVET, designed to develop skilled workers 
and craftsmen, and secondary TVET, designed to develop technicians and middle-level staff. 
The enrollment size in the TVET system is small, resulting in significant underutilization of 
existing capacity. Other key issues include the lack of quality and relevance of the TVET system 
due  to  outdated  curriculum  structure  and  contents,  aging  teachers  and  outdated  training, 
inadequate and obsolete equipment, weak institutional management, insufficient funding, and 
weak links with industry. In addition, there is limited coordination between the different types of 
TVET providers and between managing organizations in terms of planning and programs, which 
contributes to a fragmented TVET system. 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The seven priority sectors (construction, mining, energy, tourism, textiles and garment, land transport, and 
agriculture/agro-processing) jointly constitute 54% of gross domestic product and 63% of formal employment.

2 
6.  The project will build on the achievements under the first Vocational Education and Skills 
Development Project (VESDP), which is supporting reforms to the primary TVET system.3 A key 
achievement  under  VESDP  is  the  introduction  of  the  competency-based  training  (CBT) 
methodology  in  25  assisted  vocational  schools for  18  priority occupations,4 along  with  the 
improvement of the teaching and learning environment. The VESDP successfully introduced the 
full cycle of the CBT methodology.5 In May 2012, training for the pilot occupation “seamstress” 
was completed in 9 vocational schools with a total of 211 trainees, of which 185 were assessed 
and 174 passed the independent assessment conducted by accredited competency assessors 
from the textile and garment industry. The industry hired 85% of the graduates immediately. The 
initial offering of modular CBT courses for all 18 occupations in 25 vocational schools started in 
July 2012, after installation and training on the use of the new training equipment. In addition, 
the  VESDP  supported  the  first  step  in  the  rationalization  of  the  primary  TVET  system, 
consolidating 32 of 110 vocational schools in urban areas into 25 regional resource centers, 
focusing on the development of skills needed by local industries and overseas markets. It also 
supported the rehabilitation of these regional resource centers and the provision of new training 
equipment in 158 workshops. 
7.  The project will build on these achievements, and the strong foundation established in 
delivering demand-driven and relevant training programs. Support will expand to primary TVET 
in rural areas and include secondary TVET, training middle-level skilled labor for the seven 
priority  sectors,  including  information  communication  technology  as  a  cross-cutting  priority 
amongst these sectors. The project will sustain momentum among the assisted  vocational 
schools toward greater financial autonomy and sustainability by increasing their capacity to 
generate non-state-budget revenues, particularly through training fees. 
8.  The project will complement the ongoing Investment Climate Improvement Program of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB),6 which includes policy actions to leverage TVET reforms. 
On  26  March  2012,  the  Decree  on  the  National  Professional  Skills  Development  Council 
(NPSDC) was approved under subprogram 2 of the Investment Climate Improvement Program. 
NPSDC provides a framework for policymakers, employers, and key stakeholders to ensure that 
skills development efforts in the country are coordinated and responsive to labor market needs. 
The Agency for Vocational Education (AVE) in the Ministry of Youth, Labor, and Employment 
serves as NPSDC Secretariat. 
9.  The  project  is  consistent  with  national  priorities  (para.  3)  and  with  ADB’s  country 
strategy.7 Lessons learned from the VESDP will be acted on, including the need to mainstream

environments,  and  to  factor  in  the  characteristics  of  internal  and  external  migration  when 
developing TVET interventions. Under the project, ADB will work closely with other donors

B.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
10.  The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  inclusive  growth  through  greater  employment 
opportunities  for  TVET  graduates.  The  outcome  will  be  stronger  quality,  relevance,  and 
efficiency of and more equitable access to TVET. The project has four outputs; (i) primary TVET 
system  rationalized  and  TVET  system  modernized;  (ii)  TVET  teaching  and  learning 
environments  improved;  (iii)  curriculum,  and  teaching  and  learning  materials  for  TVET 
developed; and (iv) quality of TVET delivery strengthened. 
1.  Primary TVET System Rationalized and TVET System Modernized 
11.  The project will support the finalization of the primary TVET rationalization strategy 
based on a school-mapping exercise. The rationalization strategy will be implemented under the 
project. The project will support the modernization of the TVET system by making it more 
responsive  to  labor  market  needs.  The  newly  established  NPSDC  will  be  supported  by 
strengthening  AVE  as  its  secretariat  and  by  establishing  sector  councils  that  represent 
employers in the seven priority sectors. School advisory boards will be strengthened in both 
primary and secondary vocational schools to help institutionalize engagement with the private 
sector in policy formulation and help foster the entrepreneurial spirit of school management. The 
project  will  support  further  development  and  institutionalization  of  the  school  management 
system for primary vocational schools, and the publication of an annual TVET Statistical Bulletin 
and an annual tracer study of graduates. These publications will provide an analysis on the 
skills mismatches in the economy and on the disparities in employment opportunities between 
male–female and urban–rural graduates. A skills development fund will be set up to provide a 
demand-driven funding mechanism. Training needs will be identified, packaged, and awarded to 
training providers through open tender. The project will also support gender-sensitive social 
marketing campaigns intended to increase enrollment and improve the image of TVET as a 
viable educational provider for a future career. All incoming and graduating students will receive 
gender-sensitive career guidance materials. 
2.  TVET Teaching and Learning Environments Improved 
12.  The improvement of teaching and learning environments will include minor civil works9 
for rehabilitation of workshops, computer classrooms, and dormitories in vocational schools, and 
the  procurement  of  training  equipment,  furniture  and  consumables  required  for  the  newly 
developed learning materials using the CBT methodology. Support to vocational schools will be 
provided on a competitive basis. It is envisioned that 70% of the support to primary vocational 
schools will go to areas outside Bishkek and Osh. This share will be decided based on the 
school-mapping results.

3.  Curriculum, Teaching and Learning Materials for TVET Developed 
13.  The project will support the expansion of the CBT methodology in terms of the number of 
institutions and number of occupations, and institutionalize its adoption in the TVET system. 
Based on sector maps for the seven priority sectors (footnote 2), 45 priority occupations will be 
specified in close coordination with the private sector, and learning materials using the CBT 
methodology will be developed both in printed and electronic versions. The project will help 
institutionalize  TVET  reforms  through  the  development  of  national  systems  for  (i)  national 
competency standards and assessment tools, (ii) CBT curriculum and learning materials, and 
(iii) competency assessment and certification, to be adopted by AVE after review by NPSDC. 
4.  Quality of TVET Delivery Strengthened 
14.  Strengthening TVET delivery will support teacher capacity building. A TVET teaching 
qualification framework will be developed, establishing minimum requirements for teachers. 
Based  on  a  TVET  teachers'  development  program,  teachers  will  receive  national  and 
international training. The former Retraining Center under AVE will be upgraded to a Resource 
Center and will function as the training arm for continuing staff development of teachers and 
management of the TVET system. It will also undertake research on new training approaches 
and  methodologies  and  help  develop  learning  materials  for  different  TVET  programs.  In 
addition, it will serve as venue for meetings of the sector councils.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  AVE will be the executing agency of the project. AVE will appoint the project director 
who will coordinate the overall implementation of project activities. NPSDC will serve as the 
project steering committee and provide strategic guidance and monitor project implementation. 
NPSDC is chaired by the vice prime minister (social affairs) and consists of representatives from 
the government, employers, and employees. The project steering committee will meet quarterly, 
or as often as required. 
 
19.  The project will be implemented through a project implementation unit (PIU), headed by 
a  project manager  who  will  be  responsible for  overall  implementation.  A  secondary TVET 
specialist at the PIU will serve as a liaison officer with the Professional Education Department in 
the Ministry of Education and Science, and the secondary vocational schools, and will facilitate 
secondary TVET support activities that start from the second year. AVE will provide office space 
for the PIU. The PIU will report to the project director and submit quarterly progress reports to 
the project steering committee, AVE, and ADB. Project consultants supporting AVE and the 
Resource Center’s activities will be housed in their respective offices, and AVE staff will be 
assigned as counterparts to ensure knowledge transfer. 
 
20.  Staffing at AVE and the Resource Center will be realigned following the endorsement of 
the revised organizational structure of both organizations by the Ministry of Youth, Labor, and 
Employment. Following realignment, the project will support a capacity assessment and provide 
training to fill capacity gaps. Staff of AVE and the Resource Center will receive additional 
compensation for fulfillment of specific tasks in accordance with the Kyrgyz Republic legislation 
to attract and retain qualified professionals.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
23.  Sector maps for the seven priority sectors (footnote 2) were prepared to identify new 
priority occupations to be supported under the project. An occupational mapping exercise and 
survey was conducted to establish a comprehensive list of technical occupations in each of the 
seven sectors. Under the survey, employers working in priority sectors were asked to select the 
most critical occupations and skills needed for their operations, number of skilled workers 
required, difficulty in filling vacancies, and length of time needed to train new hires before they 
become  productive. This  list  of occupations  and  skills  was  then  discussed  with groups of 
experts from each sector during focus group discussions to determine the priority level of each 
occupation and related skills. The experts established a list of 78 priority occupations. As the 
project will not be able to support all priority occupations, sector councils under NPSDC will be 
requested to select the 45 most critical occupations and skills. This activity will be supported by 
the PIU as part of project preparations. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
24.  The direct economic benefits from the project are derived mainly from greater access to 
short-term  and  long-term  skills  training,  better  domestic  and  overseas  employment 
opportunities, and higher labor market outcomes for TVET graduates thanks to more relevant 
skills  training.  The  project  will  support  skills  development,  producing  graduates  with  the 
technical skills required by the seven priority sectors, and expanding their income-generating 
activities.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  the  project  is  estimated  at  20.8%.  The 
government’s contribution to the project is included in the budget and estimated at $19 million 
(Som984 million) for the primary TVET system and at $4.4 million (Som205 million) for the 
secondary  TVET  system.  Project  activities  should  be  sustainable,  taking  into  account  the 
anticipated increased proceeds through income-generating activities from vocational schools, 
which are expected to increase from 10% to 25% of total revenue, and efficiency improvements 
of the primary TVET system through rationalization. 
 
C.  Governance 
25.  Project-specific  governance  risks  have  been  analyzed  by  carrying  out  financial 
management and procurement capacity assessments of AVE and the PIU. The result of the 
financial management assessment shows that AVE has the capacity to record its financial 
transactions  and  balances,  and  to  provide  regular  and  reliable  financial  statements  and 
monitoring reports to the Ministry of Finance in accordance with government regulations. The 
PIU financial management system satisfies the financial management requirements of ADB. 
Since AVE is complying with government accounting regulations, which are different from ADB’s 
financial management requirements, the project’s financial management will not be integrated in

8 
AVE, but will remain with the PIU. In the PIU, the accounting function will remain separate from 
the  cashier  function,  to  allow  for  internal  control.  Based  on  the  procurement  capacity 
assessment, the following recommendations are made to mitigate procurement risks: (i) provide 
consulting inputs to the PIU to advise and assist in the procurement of goods and services; 
(ii) the person signing the contracts should not be part of the bid evaluation committee; and 
(iii) at least one member of the bid evaluation committee should be certified in procurement, 
either by the former State Agency for Procurement or the Procurement Unit in the Ministry of 
Finance. 
 
26.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and AVE. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM (footnote 11). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
27.  The close link between educational development and reduction in poverty incidence, 
productivity gain, economic growth, and the improvement of general living conditions is well 
established. In the case of TVET, access to quality training will expand the income-generating 
opportunities of the graduates. About 125,000 students, of which at least 30% are targeted to be 
female, will benefit from the long-term skills training, and approximately 145,000 adults and out-
of-school youths, of which at least 30% are targeted to be female, will benefit from short-term 
skills training courses during the project. New demand-driven curriculum modules, rehabilitated 
and upgraded training workshops, and practice-oriented training programs will improve income-
earning opportunities after graduation. In addition, an estimated 15,000 disadvantaged youths 
and adults, of which at least 30% are targeted to be female, will be trained under the skills 
development fund. Considering that more than 50% of youths and adults participating in training 
programs are from low-income families, the project will contribute to the enhancement of income 
opportunities for the poor. Vocational schools will benefit from increased training income, which 
will enable them to supplement the state budget, and to pay for training consumables and 
additional income for teachers. Local enterprises will benefit through increased productivity 
because of a better-skilled workforce, which in turn will contribute to the country’s economic 
competitiveness and growth. 
 
28.  The project includes a gender action plan to improve gender responsiveness. Sex-
disaggregated data will be collected on both primary and secondary TVET. Research activities 
under the project will include a separate analysis to study and report on the disparities in job 
opportunities between male and female graduates. Gender-sensitive career guidance materials 
and social marketing campaigns will be supported. At least 30% of the rehabilitated dormitories 
will be allocated to female students. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
29.  No  land  acquisition  will  be  required,  and  there  are  no  negative  environmental  or 
resettlement impacts, since the project will carry out only minor rehabilitation and repairs of 
existing school buildings and facilities. Some school rehabilitation works will improve water 
supply  and  sanitation, which  will  promote good  health.  Any  activities  that  may  cause  any 
involuntary  resettlement  impacts  will  not  be  eligible for  project financing. No  impacts from 
project activities are expected on the ethnic minorities in the country.

9 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
30.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.12 
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures  
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Sustainability of NPSDC  The key strategy to mitigate this risk is to ensure that NPSDC, a 
threatened in case of change in  high-level multisector body, can show performance through 
political leadership  endorsement and approval of well-crafted policies, plans, and 
programs on skills development. The project will support the 
secretariat of NPSDC and the sector councils, which represent 
employers in the seven priority sectors, in preparing these 
policies, plans, and programs for NPSDC approval. 
 
Limited capacity of AVE as NPSDC  The project will mitigate this risk by the ongoing review of AVE’s 
Secretariat  organizational structure and staffing to ensure that activities 
initiated under the project are mainstreamed into its regular 
functions. The competencies of AVE staff will be assessed, and 
training will be provided to fill gaps. 
 
Employers to partner slower than  The strategy to mitigate this risk is to institutionalize the 
expected with government  participation of employers in TVET, rather than doing it on an ad 
hoc basis, a lesson learned from the positive response of those 
involved in ADB’s first Vocational Education and Skills 
Development Project.a This includes establishing mechanisms 
where employers can participate in policy formulation nationally 
(NPSDC and sector councils), on operational matters in the 
schools (school advisory board), and in project-specific activities 
(e.g., MOUs with particular schools). 
 
Adaptation to reforms by school  The strategy to mitigate this risk is to manage the change 
management and staff slower than  process through (i) thorough orientation to ensure the school 
expected due to limited absorptive  management understands why changes are needed and the 
capacity  benefits that will accrue from them; and (ii) intensive training that 
provides them with knowledge and skills to be able to cope with 
the changes.

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
31.  The government and AVE have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. The government and AVE have agreed with ADB on certain 
covenants for the project, which are set forth in the financing agreement. 
                                                
12 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
32.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
 
(i)  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR6,634,000  to  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic for the Second Vocational Education and Skills Development Project, 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% 
per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 
32  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft 
financing agreement presented to the Board; and 
 
(ii)  the grant not exceeding $10,000,000 to the Kyrgyz Republic, from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources, for the Second Vocational Education and Skills Development 
Project, on terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance with those 
set forth in the draft financing agreement presented to the Board.
